The Committee on Appropriations amends Section 302(b) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to include committee suballocations after consulting with the other House's Committee on Appropriations. The joint resolution must include a subdivision among its subcommittees of the allocation of budget outlays and new budget authority. The joint resolution must include a subdivision among its subcommittees of the allocation of budget outlays and new budget authority, as well as a subdivision of the amount with respect to each subcommittee between controllable amounts and all other amounts. The resolution will be placed on the calendar for disposition according to the rules outlined in this subsection. The provisions for the consideration of concurrent resolutions on the budget and conference reports in the Senate will also apply to the consideration of this joint resolution. The joint resolution reported under this paragraph in the Senate will have limited debate time of 20 hours. The Committee on Appropriations will manage the resolution, and the allocations of the Committees on Appropriations will only take effect once the resolution is enacted into law. The debatable motions and appeals related to the joint resolution shall be limited to 20 hours. The Committee on Appropriations will oversee the resolution, and the allocations of the Committees on Appropriations will not be effective until the resolution becomes law. Other committees will subdivide their allocations among subcommittees or programs after consulting with relevant committees from the other House. The explanatory statement requires committees to subdivide allocations among subcommittees or programs and further divide the amount between controllable and other amounts. Committees must report these subdivisions to their respective Houses. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act regarding the allocation process. Amendments are made to the Congressional Budget Act regarding the allocation process, including alterations of allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations. Amendments to the Congressional Budget Act allow for alterations of allocations proposed by the Committee on Appropriations, subject to approval and consistency with previous actions. Amendments to appropriations bill include changes to Section 302 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974, allowing for floor amendments that reduce budget authority and subcommittee allocations. The appropriations bill amendments can reduce budget authority and subcommittee allocations, affecting discretionary spending limits for the fiscal year and subsequent years. Conference reports on the bill cannot contain provisions that decrease subcommittee allocations and discretionary spending included in both the Senate and House versions. The rule prohibits conference reports on appropriations bills from reducing subcommittee allocations and discretionary spending below the levels in the Senate or House versions. SEC. 4 amends Section 602(b)(1) of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 regarding suballocations by appropriations committees.
